docs.snippet: South Korean prosecutors have charged Tatsuya Kato, the former Seoul bureau chief for the Japanese newspaper Sankei Shimbun, with defaming the South Korean president.
docs.lead_paragraph: South Korean prosecutors have charged Tatsuya Kato, the former Seoul bureau chief for the Japanese newspaper Sankei Shimbun, with defaming the South Korean president.
docs.abstract: Japan protests filing of charges against Japanese journalist Tatsuya Kato, former Seoul bureau chief for Japanese newspaper Sankei Shimbun, in Seoul; South Korean prosecutors have charged Kato with defaming South Korean Pres Park Geun-hye.

headline.main: Japan Protests Indictment of Journalist by South Korea
headline.print_headline: Japan Protests an Indictment of a Journalist

docs.snippet: Prosecutors indicted a Japanese journalist on charges he defamed South Korea’s president by reporting rumors that she was absent for seven hours during the April ferry disaster because she was with a man.
docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors indicted a Japanese journalist on charges he defamed South Korea’s president by reporting rumors that she was absent for seven hours during the April ferry disaster because she was with a man.
docs.abstract: South Korean prosecutors indict Japanese journalist Tatsuya Kato on charges he defamed South Korea’s Pres Park Geun-hye by reporting rumors that she was absent for seven hours during the April ferry disaster because she was with a man.

headline.main: South Korea: Journalist Is Charged Over Report on Rumors About President
headline.print_headline: South Korea: Journalist Is Charged Over Report on Rumors About President

docs.snippet: The coast guard had sought to impound a Chinese fishing boat it said was illegally fishing in South Korean waters, officials said.
docs.lead_paragraph: The coast guard had sought to impound a Chinese fishing boat it said was illegally fishing in South Korean waters, officials said.

headline.main: Fisherman From China Dies in Clash Off S. Korea
headline.print_headline: Fisherman From China Dies in Clash Off S. Korea

byline.contributor: Jane Perlez contributed reporting from Beijing.

docs.snippet: The artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at an elite he considers responsible for a deadly ferry disaster, and has faced censorship he likens to his treatment during years of dictatorship.
docs.lead_paragraph: The artist Hong Sung-dam lashed out at an elite he considers responsible for a deadly ferry disaster, and has faced censorship he likens to his treatment during years of dictatorship.
docs.abstract: South Korean government, in unusual display of censorship, pulls large painting by dissident artist Hong Sung-dam from international art festival; Hong has been outspoken in his opposition to Pres Park Geun-hye's government, echoing widespread criticism of its botched rescue effort following ferry disaster, lax oversight, and resistance to a broad independent investigation.

headline.main: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Korea’s Leader in an Unflattering Light
headline.print_headline: An Artist Is Rebuked for Casting South Korea’s Leader in an Unflattering Light

docs.snippet: Mary Barra, G.M.’s chief executive, lands a Time magazine cover; G.M. and Isuzu to collaborate on global midsize pickup.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Barra, G.M.’s chief executive, lands a Time magazine cover; G.M. and Isuzu to collaborate on global midsize pickup.

docs.snippet: In a conciliatory gesture after years of tensions, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan sent a letter to President Park Geun-hye of South Korea proposing the meeting.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a conciliatory gesture after years of tensions, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan sent a letter to President Park Geun-hye of South Korea proposing the meeting.
docs.abstract: Office of South Korean Pres Park Geun-hye says Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe has sent letter proposing summit meeting, conciliatory gesture after years of tensions between the two countries.

headline.main: Japan’s Premier Seeks Summit Meeting With South Korean President
headline.print_headline: South Korea: Japan Proposes a Meeting

docs.snippet: The United States has approved anti-dumping duties against South Korea and other producers of steel pipes for the energy sector.

docs.snippet: After South Korean activists sent anti-Pyongyang leaflets across the border and troops from both sides exchanged fire, the state news agency said talks with Seoul could be canceled.

docs.snippet: The move comes a month after The Asahi Shimbun retracted articles on another hot-button issue about Japan’s wartime legacy: women forced to serve in brothels.

docs.abstract: Japanese newspaper Asahi Simbun retracts influential report on Fukushima nuclear disaster, and issues apology.
